newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Philippines studying Russian offer of MiG-29s.
newsitem.headline: Philippines studying Russian offer of MiG-29s.

text.p: The Philippine armed forces is studying a Russian offer of a fleet of MiG-29 aircraft to help modernise the country's ill-equipped air force, military sources said on Friday.

If the government takes up the offer, it will most likely include a countertrade arrangement under which part of the payment will be in the form of commodities, said a senior officer, who asked not to be identified.
A Russian diplomatic source said representatives from Moscow Aviation Production Organisation (Mapo) were expected to visit the Philippines in the next few weeks to discuss the proposal.

Defence Secretary Renato de Villa told Reuters last month the Philippines planned to spend about $2 billion over the next five years to modernise the defence forces with more fighter planes and patrol ships.
The five-year weapons acquisition plan is the first phase of a 15-year military modernisation programme which would cost a total of $12 billion.
"Everybody is trying to offer the Philippines something for modernisation," the Russian source said. He said he did not have details of the offer for MiG-29s.
Philipine armed forces chief General Arnulfo Acedera and senior officers for planning and logistics visited Russia last August and were shown several of the fighters.
The Philippine air force temporarily grounded its fleet of 10 ageing F-5 fighter jets in January after one of the aircraft nose-dived into a river bank, killing two people, including its pilot.
Investigators said the crash was apparently caused by mechanical failure.
Most of the country's fighter jets were acquired from the United States in the 1960s.
